author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Secondly, it may be objected that experience seems to teach us
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Nothing therefore seems to be taught more clearly by experience,
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: than another; in  other words, that we do not seem to need for
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that  one idea has more reality or perfection than another, for
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Fourthly, it  may be objected, if man does not act from free
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will, what will happen if the incentives to  action are equally
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: balanced, as in the case of Buridan's ass?  Will he perish of
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hunger and  thirst?  If I say that he would not, he would then
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: determine his own action, and would  consequently possess the
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: faculty of going and doing whatever he liked.  Other objections
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: might also be raised, but, as I am not bound to put in evidence
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: everything that anyone may  dream, I will only set myself to the
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: task of refuting those I have mentioned, and that as  briefly as
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: possible.
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: To the first objection I answer, that I admit that the will has a
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wider scope than the  understanding, if by the understanding be
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: meant only clear and distinct ideas; but I deny  that the will
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: has a wider scope than the perceptions, and the faculty of
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: forming  conceptions; nor do I see why the faculty of volition
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: should be called infinite, any more  than the faculty of feeling:
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for, as we are able by the same faculty of volition to affirm an
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinite number of things (one after the other, for we cannot
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affirm an infinite number  simultaneously), so also can we, by
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the same faculty of feeling, feel or perceive (in  succession) an
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinite number of bodies.  If it be said that there is an
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinite number of  things which we cannot perceive, I answer,
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that we cannot attain to such things by any  thinking, nor,
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequently, by any faculty of volition.  But, it may still be
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: urged, if God  wished to bring it about that we should perceive
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: them, he would be obliged to endow us  with a greater faculty of
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perception, but not a greater faculty of volition than we have
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: already.  This is the same as to say that, if God wished to bring
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it about that we should  understand an infinite number of other
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: entities, it would be necessary for him to give us a  greater
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understanding, but not a more universal idea of entity than that
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which we have  already, in order to grasp such infinite entities.
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: We have shown that will is a universal  entity or idea, whereby
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we explain all particular volitions--in other words, that which
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is  common to all such volitions.
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: As, then, our opponents maintain that this idea, common or
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: universal to all volitions, is a  faculty, it is little to be
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wondered at that they assert, that such a faculty extends itself
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: into  the infinite, beyond the limits of the understanding:  for
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: what is universal is predicated alike  of one, of many, and of an
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinite number of individuals.
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: To the second objection I reply by denying, that we have a free
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power of suspending  our judgment:  for, when we say that anyone
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: suspends his judgment, we merely mean that  he sees, that he does
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not perceive the matter in question adequately.  Suspension of
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: judgment is, therefore, strictly speaking, a perception, and not
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: free will.  In order to  illustrate the point, let us suppose a
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: boy imagining a horse, and perceive nothing else.   Inasmuch as
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this imagination involves the existence of the horse (II. xvii.
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Cor.), and the boy  does not perceive anything which would
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: exclude the existence of the horse, he will  necessarily regard
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the horse as present:  he will not be able to doubt of its
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existence,  although he be not certain thereof.  We have daily
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: experience of such a state of things in  dreams; and I do not
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: suppose that there is anyone, who would maintain that, while he
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is  dreaming, he has the free power of suspending his judgment
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: concerning the things in his  dream, and bringing it about that
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he should not dream those things, which he dreams that  he sees;
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: yet it happens, notwithstanding, that even in dreams we suspend
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: our judgment,  namely, when we dream that we are dreaming.
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Further, I grant that no one can be deceived, so far as actual
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perception extends--that is, I  grant that the mind's
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imaginations, regarded in themselves, do not involve error (II.
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xvii.  note); but I deny, that a man does not, in the act of
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perception, make any affirmation.  For  what is the perception of
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a winged horse, save affirming that a horse has wings?  If the
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind could perceive nothing else but the winged horse, it would
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: regard the same as present  to itself:  it would have no reasons
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for doubting its existence, nor any faculty of dissent,  unless
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the imagination of a winged horse be joined to an idea which
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: precludes the  existence of the said horse, or unless the mind
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perceives that the idea which it possess of a  winged horse is
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: inadequate, in which case it will either necessarily deny the
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: existence of  such a horse, or will necessarily be in doubt on
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the subject.
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I think that I have anticipated my answer to the third objection,
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: namely, that the will is  something universal which is predicated
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of all ideas, and that it only signifies that which is  common to
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: all ideas, namely, an affirmation, whose adequate essence must,
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, in  so far as it is thus conceived in the abstract, be
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in every idea, and be, in this respect alone,  the same in all,
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not in so far as it is considered as constituting the idea's
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: essence:  for, in  this respect, particular affirmations differ
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: one from the other, as much as do ideas.  For  instance, the
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affirmation which involves the idea of a circle, differs from
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that which  involves the idea of a triangle, as much as the idea
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of a circle differs from the idea of a  triangle.
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Further, I absolutely deny, that we are in need of an equal power
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of thinking, to affirm  that that which is true is true, and to
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affirm that that which is false is true.  These two
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affirmations, if we regard the mind, are in the same relation to
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: one another as being and  not-being; for there is nothing
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: positive in ideas, which constitutes the actual reality of
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: falsehood (II. xxxv. note, and xlvii. note).
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: We must therefore conclude, that we are easily deceived, when we
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: confuse universals with  singulars, and the entities of reason
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and abstractions with realities.  As for the fourth  objection, I
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: am quite ready to admit, that a man placed in the equilibrium
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: described  (namely, as perceiving nothing but hunger and thirst,
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a certain food and a certain drink,  each equally distant from
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: him) would die of hunger and thirst.  If I am asked, whether such
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: an one should not rather be considered an ass than a man; I
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: answer, that I do not know,  neither do I know how a man should
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be considered, who hangs himself, or how we should  consider
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: children, fools, madmen, &c.
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: It remains to point out the advantages of a knowledge of this
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: doctrine as bearing on  conduct, and this may be easily gathered
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from what has been said.  The doctrine is good,
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: 1. Inasmuch as it teaches us to act solely according to the
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: decree of God, and to be  partakers in the Divine nature, and so
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: much the more, as we perform more perfect actions  and more and
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: more understand God.  Such a doctrine not only completely
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: tranquilizes our  spirit, but also shows us where our highest
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: happiness or blessedness is, namely, solely in  the knowledge of
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God, whereby we are led to act only as love and piety shall bid
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: us.  We  may thus clearly understand, how far astray from a true
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: estimate of virtue are those who  expect to be decorated by God
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with high rewards for their virtue, and their best actions,  as
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for having endured the direst slavery; as if virtue and the
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: service of God were not in  itself happiness and perfect freedom.
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: 2. Inasmuch as it teaches us, how we ought to conduct ourselves
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with respect to the gifts  of fortune, or matters which are not
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in our power, and do not follow from our nature.  For  it shows
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: us, that we should await and endure fortune's smiles or frowns
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with an equal  mind, seeing that all things follow from the
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: eternal decree of God by the same necessity,  as it follows from
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the essence of a triangle, that the three angles are equal to two
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: right  angles.
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: 3. This doctrine raises social life, inasmuch as it teaches us to
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hate no man, neither to  despise, to deride, to envy, or to be
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: angry with any.  Further, as it tells us that each should  be
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: womanish pity,  favour, or superstition, but solely by the
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: 4. Lastly, this doctrine confers no small advantage on the
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whatsoever things are best.
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I have thus fulfilled the promise made at the beginning of this
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: note, and I thus bring the  second part of my treatise to a
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: close.  I think I have therein explained the nature and
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: properties of the human mind at sufficient length, and,
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: considering the difficulty of the  subject, with sufficient
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: clearness.  I have laid a foundation, whereon may be raised many
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: excellent conclusions of the highest utility and most necessary
title: Ethics — Part 2
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to be known, as will, in  what follows, be partly made plain.
